content.raw: Will merge on Monday if there are no comments.
content.html: Will merge on Monday if there are no comments.

content.raw:
I don’t see a problem with this, although I will point out you could work around it by placing your connection table code in a function, and calling that function from your main script to ensure the code runs every time!

This PR is probably useful for a lot of other things too \(like importing labscript, since I think module watcher doesn’t watch that for some reason…\)
content.html:
I don’t see a problem with this, although I will point out you could work around it by placing your connection table code in a function, and calling that function from your main script to ensure the code runs every time!

This PR is probably useful for a lot of other things too (like importing labscript, since I think module watcher doesn’t watch that for some reason…)

content.raw:
Yes, that would do it too! Neither approach is completely satisfactory, but whatever.

Labscript is whitelisted by modulewatcher because it is already imported by the time the script runs - batch\_compiler.py needs to call labscript\_init\(\) with the h5 file. Reloading labscipt would result in the new labscript module not knowing what the h5 file was! Not sure if there’s much of a way around that, other than restarting the compiler subprocess.
content.html:
Yes, that would do it too! Neither approach is completely satisfactory, but whatever.

Labscript is whitelisted by modulewatcher because it is already imported by the time the script runs - batch_compiler.py needs to call labscript_init() with the h5 file. Reloading labscipt would result in the new labscript module not knowing what the h5 file was! Not sure if there’s much of a way around that, other than restarting the compiler subprocess.
